div.head: Chapter 16
div.p: Cursed, cursed creator! Why did I live? Why, in that instant, did I not extinguish the spark of existence which you had so wantonly bestowed? I know not; despair had not yet taken possession of me; my feelings were those of rage and revenge...
div.note: This opening demonstrates the Creature's intense existential despair and rage against Victor Frankenstein, highlighting the central theme of creator and creation. Mary Shelley, Frankenstein, 1818.
div.p: When night came I quitted my retreat and wandered in the wood; and now, no longer restrained by the fear of discovery, I gave vent to my anguish in fearful howlings...
div.note: Shelley's use of natural imagery (the "cold stars" and "bare trees") contrasts the Creature's inner turmoil, reinforcing the Romantic preoccupation with nature's indifference. Critical Source: Mellor, Anne K. "Mary Shelley: Her Life, Her Fiction, Her Monsters," 1988.
div.p: The sun rose; I heard the voices of men and knew that it was impossible to return to my retreat during that day...
div.note: The Creature's reflection on his "imprudence" emphasizes his capacity for moral reasoning, challenging assumptions about his monstrosity. Secondary Source: Cantor, Paul A. "Frankenstein as Modern Myth," 1976.
div.p: The pleasant sunshine and the pure air of day restored me to some degree of tranquillity; and when I considered what had passed at the cottage...
As night advanced, I placed a variety of combustibles around the cottage...
div.note: The act of burning the cottage symbolizes the Creature's descent into vengeance and mirrors Victor's destructive obsession with knowledge. Mary Shelley, Frankenstein, 1818.
div.p: And now, with the world before me, whither should I bend my steps? I resolved to fly far from the scene of my misfortunes...
At this time a slight sleep relieved me from the pain of reflection, which was disturbed by the approach of a beautiful child...
div.note: The encounter with the child demonstrates the Creature's conflicting desire for connection and capacity for violence when rejected. Critical Analysis: Baldick, Chris. "In Frankenstein's Shadow," 1987.
div.p: "Boy, you will never see your father again; you must come with me."
The child still struggled and loaded me with epithets which carried despair to my heart...
"This was then the reward of my benevolence! I had saved a human being from destruction, and as a recompense I now writhed under the miserable pain of a wound...
div.note: The Creature's wound becomes symbolic of the emotional and physical suffering inflicted by humanity's rejection. Mary Shelley, Frankenstein, 1818.
div.p: "After some weeks my wound healed, and I continued my journey. The labours I endured were no longer to be alleviated by the bright sun or gentle breezes of spring...
But my toils now drew near a close, and in two months from this time I reached the environs of Geneva...
div.note: Geneva, Victor's birthplace, serves as a geographical marker for the Creature's growing identification of Victor as the source of his misery. Historical Context: Wolfson, Susan J. "Borderlines: The Shiftings of Gender in British Romanticism," 2006.
